video.title: Learn Unreal Engine (with C++) - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn Unreal Engine in this full tutorial using C++. In this beginner's course, you will how to create three full games with Unreal Engine and Blueprints.

🎥 Course from Awesome Tuts. Check out their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5c-DuzPdH9iaWYdI0v0uzw
🔗 Learn more about game development here: https://www.awesometuts.com/ultimate-game-dev-academy?utm_medium=youtube&utm_source=freecodecamp&utm_campaign=unreal_tutorial

⭐️Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️(0:00:45) Battery Collector Game
  💻Project Code: https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/NZVRzw8JTtWXHuGIJeCQ

⌨️(1:16:10) Brick Breaker Game
  💻Project Code: https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/MdZBi35CTwSV9gJT9zFi
  💻Assets: https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/nrDnHoOuTWGbNkWJUtMz

⌨️(2:39:52) Pacman
  💻Project Code: https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/0D0tNZ6ERYagcNupZGbD
  💻Assets: https://www.filepicker.io/api/file/uASaLcXOQR2uIJLqW4Mv

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: SkyAbyss
topLevelComment.text:
First Game:
Collision Issue Fix UE5 

Sphere Thingy (PickableItem_BP):
Box component:
- Set Box as a sub component of StaticMesh
- Scale : 1 / 1 / 1
Go to Shape : 
- Set Box Extent to 120 / 120 / 120 (maybe this is a locale case)
-If the Box from the previous case is too large set the values so that the box exceeds the mesh a little

Box Collision Settings : 
- Generate Overlap Events - check
- Collision Presets - Custom...
- Collision Enabled : Query Only (No Physics Collision)
- Object Type : WorldDynamic
- Set Pawn to Overlap
- Rest of them to Block

Character BP (BatteryMan_BP) Capsule Component : 
- Generate Overlap Events - Check
- Collision Presets - Pawn

EDIT:
Second game:

Around 1:30:30 if your engine crashes move the SM_Padle->SetConstraintMode(EDOFMode::XZPlane); in BeginPlay().


Hope it helps.

topLevelComment.author: red Itlord
topLevelComment.text:
Don't know if it will help someone, but at 1:50:43 if the paddle doesn't move when pressing the key, remember to first click on the viewport first. My code was right but I take lot of time to remember that I had to click on the viewport ^^

Edit : Also if anyone had troubles with trying to resolve the Collision that don't trigger sometimes at 2:31:27 I encourage you to take some times to try more, but it took me so much time to solve this that I might give my solution ( I looked a lot on google and found nothing ). So the thing is to use OnActorHit.AddDynamic instead of OnComponentOverlapBegin.AddDynamic, OnHit seems way more stable than overlapping. But a thing that he doesn't explain in the video is that the function passed as a parameter in AddDynamic has to have certain parameters that match the event : 
 In the video OnOverlapBegin(UPrimitiveComponent * OverlappedComp, AActor * OtherActor, UPrimitiveComponent * OtherComp, int32 OtherBodyIndexType, bool bFromSweep, const FHitResult & SweepResult) has to be replace by OnHit or whatever name you want to call it but it has to have the parameters OnHit(AActor* SelfActor, AActor* OtherActor, FVector NormalImpulse, const FHitResult& Hit). This list of parameters is called a signature and has to match absolutly the signature needed by the event (OnComponentOverlapBegin, OnComponentOverlapEnd, OnActorHit ect...).

topLevelComment.author: Gaël Renault
topLevelComment.text: Hey mate, thanks so much for your videos, they are very helpful. One thing i just want to point out though, despite how good you are at teaching, is i think the gap between your first playlist (C++ for Unreal Engine) and this course, is a bit too consequent. What i mean by that is that there are tons of functions, such as FRotator, bUse etc... that are not clearly defined. But other than that, keep the good work. You are very good source of knowledge !

replies.author: Gaël Renault
replies.text:
@EmEm MeMe That's not the point, and i'm ok, specially since then. I just think the gap between his C++ playlist and this one is too important. For example, he does not talk about pointers arithmetics, templates, smart pointers, macros, preprocessing, function pointers, lambdas, unions, Lvalues, Rvalues, dynamic memory allocation, etc... 

Unreal C++ is not only requiring these notions and more, but the C++ in Unreal is very specific, and hard (almost every function is a C++ macro, there are sublclasses of subclasses of classes etc...), if not impossible to understand for someone whom has only watched the first playlist.

Besides, learning BP has nothing to do with learning C++. Blueprints don't need all of these notions, but in order to be mastered, you probably need to already be a good C++ programmer to understand all the nuances and subtlety.

What would be interesting, is a video on how Unreal uses C++. I mean, explain what are UFUNCTIONS, UPROPERTIES, why most methods return pointers and not references, etc...

replies.author: EmEm MeMe
replies.text: if you find those difficult to understand, then you should start with blueprints first

replies.author: Gaël Renault
replies.text: II'm going to rephrase what i said. Your explanations are good, however, i think you should spend more time explaining what is what. Let aside the specific C++ functions in Unreal, such as FRotator etc, you could say for exemple, ok, FollowCamera is a pointer, "CreateDefaultSubobject" is a class template, and USpringArmComponent is a type of primitive, or, properties such as UFUNCTIONS are actually macros, etc...

topLevelComment.text: Was anybody able to figure out why the collisions are inconsistent in the Arkanoid game?

replies.author: What's Happening, Harlow?!
replies.text:
Open up the Static Mesh asset that you’re using for this component and then select the “Collision” button on the toolbar at the top to turn on the visualization. Does a wireframe that represents the collision show up? If not, try selecting the Collision dropdown and selecting one of the add options to add a default collision.

If it’s still not working after doing this, try dropping the mesh itself into the level and see if the character will collide with it.

replies.author: Zayadur
replies.text:
Make sure you have Visual Studio 2019. Launch the Visual Studio Installer, click on "Modify" on your Visual Studio 2019 installation, go to the "Individual components" tab, and scroll all the way down to find Windows SDK versions and install one of them.

If you prefer the packages under the "Workloads" tab, install the "Desktop development with C++" and "Game development with C++". Both packages include the Windows SDK.

first time you write along and dont get anything, you wonder about a few things but lots are left to wonder about, and few answers to the stuff you wonder about show up or pop up in brain
second time, you can kinda fast forward, type it out real quick - and as you do so, brain starts to connect some more dots
and then it takes like less time than the video to go thru it all and it feels kickass and since things aren't spread apart by time.. brain connects even more dots

after a few projects, you'll see a lot of the why how when and where.. now stfu and go do something ;)

topLevelComment.author: Genius Pancake
topLevelComment.text:
I don't recommend beginners to follow this tutorial, this is not the video for you, at all. If you want to learn from this video, 99% of the work will need to be by your own research. So, if that is the case, every time he implements something you do not understand, and he never explains these things...ever, you need to stop the video...google what he did...research...understand...continue the video for 5 seconds...repeat.

Understanding coding is not trying to copy/paste a video and say "look, it works!". The moment you need to do it on your own, you will realize that this video was a complete waste of your time, unless you did the steps I wrote. 

He knows UE4 C++, but in this video he was not a good tutor.

replies.author: TheTrifel
replies.text:
When you create the class 
Say actor c++ class 
You can name it in the name section  
And in the second section under name just add a /foldername to the path there , and it will create the folder and place your actor.class in the newly created folder as it compiles and opens vs 

Then when you go back in the editor , you will have a new folder in your c++ section 

It doesn't allow you to do it in editor at all for anything c++ related

Add...
You can do it in vs , but you will have to change headers ,after you manually shuffle the classes and add/move the files or folders to your desired structure in gamename/source folder  ,then regenerate solution and open and rebuild after adjusting the affected headers and files 

It's a bit tedious to shuffle folders after things have been moved,  I just notice if you make changes to the structure in vs you still will have to manually move it in your explorer or things break , so personally I do the changes and add folders etc in vs , open windows explorer to your structure set what is needed ,move what is needed , open vs , change headers to new paths wait for intellisense 😆, and build again 

Seems to work for me

topLevelComment.author: Mad Haytur
topLevelComment.text: Wish this would fully explain what the arrow operator does. I haven't seen any tutorials for it on unreal at all.

replies.author: lalilulelo
replies.text: It's a general C++ operator. It calls the given method on the object that the pointer is pointing to. If you have a class Dog and you create a pointer like Dog *pointerToDog, you will create an instance (object) of the class Dog in your Ram. The pointer you created can be used to access that space in memory containing your object. To call methods on that object you use the arrow operator on the pointer: pointerToDog->DoSomethingToDog(); is equivalent to (*pointerToDog).DoSomethingToDog(). The asterisk before a pointer is used to de-reference, which means to get the object you're pointing at rather than the pointer itself. Note that the method acts on a Dog object, not a pointer to a Dog, so you need the arrow operator in order to use that method. ( pointerToDog.DoSomethingToDog() would give you an error)

topLevelComment.text: learning a lot, great vid, but in the first lesson with the batteries one of the things you didnt seem to understand was that when you set physics enabled on the non root component, which is the static mesh, the static mesh simulates physics, but none of the other subobjects do, meaning: the box collision remains at it's world origin.. so collision was only triggered when you moved into that,(before you attempted to *fix it) if you dont believe set the box to non hidden, and you will see it does not move with the actor... if you wanted the box to move with the static mesh you could have set the static mesh as the root component and the box as a suboject of that... and for this example, you didnt even need the box collision, since you enabled collision on the static mesh itself... just a bit of time wasted with that bad explanation of collision settings...

replies.author: Litmus
replies.text: C++ just has a different purpose. There's a lot of things you can't do in blueprint. Things like slate, plugins for external code. Or even just calling functions or reading/writing data to things not exposed to unreal reflection. It's also very useful for debugging and figuring things out that haven't been documented. As well having a huge readability advantage over large blueprints. C++ is also much faster at runtime; yes there's nativization but it produces nonsense code and isn't perfectly optimised. It's just not possible to reason about writing fast code in blueprint, things like cache locality just sort of go out the window.

topLevelComment.author: Arno Pisspot
topLevelComment.text: I don’t get the format behind these long format videos. Instead of a 4 hour video, create a playlist with multiple 10-15 minute videos. It will be easier to digest, you get more views, and easier for the viewer to navigate  and go back to the different videos when he needs to review something.  If you want to get an idea go watch the netninja YouTube channel and see his playlist. It’s like a library where everything is organized and easy to find.

replies.author: freeCodeCamp.org
replies.text: It may seem counterintuitive but our experience is people end up watching more of these longer videos, and coming back to them. Also it's a lot easier to share or embed a single video than it is an entire YouTube playlist. We add time codes to the descriptions so people can get to the part of the video they want to see.
